title: How should I answer essay questions that begin with the word “evaluate”? - Quora

response.answer_text: To evaluate, I would suggest you try: make clear to yourself and the reader what was intended to be achieved, how and by whom and in what timescale.If many things needed to be achieved, you may have to deal with them as a whole or one by one, a paragraph at a time or make a timeline for yourself and, maybe for the reader.review each of those aspects one by one, but in the order of who & how (because they interlace) and then the big one…what was actually achieved.Then why you think the outcome was a close or poor match for the intentionAnd/or in what way it could have been done better.This is a very general idea, but with a bit of thought and adaptation, you can apply it to anything from Ulysses to the Aswan Dam to Brexit.

Evaluate: It will be necessary to compare one thing to other things. That is the basic understanding that you need. To proceed, you will need to study the history of your subject. Part of your evaluation will be a brief summary of your subject. The other part will review the relationship of your subject to science, theology, philosophy, or law. Gather all of the available information, and then proceed. Other knowledge domains may be applicable, such as economics, fine arts and other subjects.

Blooms will help you with that: https://www.csun.edu/science/ref/reasoning/questions_blooms/blooms.html I think Neil Barnett has the right of it. Just make sure you lay out, very clearly, your criteria—what you think the thing was designed for and what it should be able to accomplish. Make sure, also, that you give specifics on how you think it accomplished those criteria or where it fell short (and why.)

Begin with understanding what you are supposed to evaluate. Then write a mini-outline before writing your response. Make sure you have a thesis statement and main points supported by facts or valid opinions. With all the questions of any type, including true/false, multiple choice and short answer, make sure you pay just as much attention to the questions as you do the answers.
good calculated answers given by Bruce Bain and Neil Barnet…
